A recent, comprehensive literature survey of human pathogens listed >1,400 different species (
1 ), more than half known to be zoonotic, i.e., able to infect other host species (
1
,
2 ). The survey data showed that those pathogens regarded as emerging and reemerging were more likely to be zoonotic than those that are not (
1
,
3 ), confirming an association between these characteristics which had long been suspected (
4
,
5 ), but which could not be formally demonstrated without denominator data as well as numerator data.
